captions.text:
Good morning John. Guess what's behind this
thing? New York City!

And guess what's behind this thing? It's me.
I'm at home again.

I was in New York because SciShow just got
a big new sponsor, and we we doing press tours,

talking to people, anyone who would listen
to us about science education and stuff.

You may have noticed that we've never, ever
done a branded video here on Vlogbrothers-

this is not one of those. They don't know
that I'm making this video.

Emerson, for the most part, makes stuff that
you would never buy, unless you, like, own

a power plant, or a Fortune 500 company, or
something.

And so the advertisements we're doing together
aren't about getting people to buy their products,
because that's not the problem they have.

The problem they have is that they solve big
engineering problems and big science problems
and to do that they need scientists and engineers.

And with not as many people graduating with
so-called 'STEM degrees,' and more people

going to work for big new companies that you've
heard of like Google and and SpaceX and Tesla,
they're a little worried.

And I share their worry, though for separate
reasons. I don't hire engineer people- for

the most part, I hire humanities people. Like
writers, and video editors, and artists, and
stuff.

I'm concerned because scientists and engineers
solve a lot of the big problems that we need

to solve, like how do we get clean water to
more people? And how do we continue to power

this amazing lifestyle that I get to lead
without destroying the world?

So yeah, when this came to SciShow, I was
like, "Oh, this makes sense, actually. We
will do that."

That STEM toolkit is a very valuable one,
and one that is being developed less often

by people. And what I kept being asked by
people on TV and radio was "Why? Why are fewer
people doing this?"

And I'm not an expert on that; I went through
school one time. That's pretty much all my

data. But as with most things, my guess is
it's a lot of different reasons.

And one reason is that I think it's really
hard, and we just kind of sugarcoat it sometimes,

but it is hard, and that's huge amount of
information to stick into your brain.

But I think, more than that, we're also told
that there's a certain type of person who

becomes a scientist or an engineer, and they're
just good at it. They're just good at math,

and they're good at science, and just engineering
geniuses!

And that's a really dangerous myth, because
everyone I know who went through a science

or engineering degree, it was really hard
for them. It was really hard for me.

Nobody is born being good at math. I think
some people are born really liking that challenge.

That's the thing that all of the scientists
I know have in common.

Like, there's no other common trait amongst
them. They're mothers and rock climbers and

punk rockers. Some are into politics, or sports,
or spend their evenings on Tumblr.

The only thing they have in common is that
passion for solving hard problems. And there

are certainly non-science problems that need
to be solved as well. That's why I hire lots

of artists and animators and video editors
and stuff.

I think often when we tell people to get into
STEM careers, it's not because it's interesting

or fascinating or cool, it's because that's
the best way to get a good job, so do that.

If you don't do this terribly difficult thing,
then you will never get a good job. And I

think that's a terrible thing to do to a child,
who is like fifteen years old. They're in

high school, and you're telling them, "Okay,
just start panicking now. A decade before
you will be done learning all of these things."

That's-that's terrifying! We can't we, instead,
treat this like every other big problem and

take it one step at a time, being driven by
not the end goal, but by, you know, interests,
and fascinations along the way.

And I wanna say the most interesting toolkit
you can have is one that includes both and

technology, engineering and liberal arts.
That's the education I had, and I'm so grateful
for it.

Anyway, this really is a career path that's
open to everyone. So that's why I was in New

York; I was doing things with them. And seeing
lots of my friends and hanging out with cool
people, that was fun too.

The advertisement we made together, just encouraging
people to be interested and fascinated by

science, is running now. There's also a link
below -- you can see it on YouTube.

And if you're thinking to yourself, "Hank,
you were in New York City and you did not

tell me and I did not get to see you that
is so uncool," I was very busy.

But also, I will be back! In April! With Harry
and the Potters, Driftless Pony Club, Andrew

Huang, Rob Scallon, playing music all, from
like Chicago, all the way to New York, there's

like eight stops. You can check out more information
in the link in the description. Tour Because
Awesome: East Coast!
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

comments.text:
I think the main issue with why people can't make it through STEM careers 
is that the education system spends too much time on review (like another 
poster said), but then we try to cram all the real learning in that last 
5-7 years of schooling (Junior year-college). If we start teaching kids 
YOUNG then they won't find STEM as difficult as they do.
Imagine you waited until your Junior year of high school to write your 
first book report.. yeah that's essentially what we do to kids in math and 
science. The truth is *the average 4th grader can probably handle high 
school algebra fine*, but they aren't introduced to it until their 7-10th 
grade years so the entire foundation for learning is shaky to begin with so 
when they get into Calculus II in college that's literally the first time 
they've ever seen that material and there's no wonder why they have a hard 
time grasping it in only a semester. They're already so used to going over 
the same information repeatedly for 2-4 years so when you cram everything 
into 4-9 months yeah... they're gonna have trouble grasping the concept.

What we should do is stop spending so much time on review and spending more 
time on building. I have a friend that homeschools her kids and she told me 
that pretty much every year is a review of the last which is why she can 
have a 14 year old working on 11th grade material with no issues on his 
part. Her son isn't a super genius.. they just spend much less time on 
review than traditional American schools do. I don't think it'd be a 
stretch to say that out of the 9 months of any given school year 4-5 of 
those months are based purely on *review* while you're only learning about 
4-5 months of new material. There's no wonder that when students go to the 
format of learning by the semester without such high emphasis on review 
when they get to college they struggle so badly.﻿

This is my theory of why there is a shortage of people in science and math. 
It is designed that way. Before  the WWII, Korean and Vietnamese War a 
small percentage of people went to war, but that changed with the GI Bill 
as more and more people became educated. As a huge influx of college 
students began going to college so did people obtaining degrees in very 
lucrative careers. Doctors, architects, engineering, accounting ect.
 
An influx of to many people in these careers devalued the careers, which in 
returned threatened the compensation for these careers. As a result doctors 
began placing barriers of entry into the medical field. These practices 
eventually found their way into the education system and other 
math/sciences that are purposely used to "weed out" potential competition 
in the career. As a result people who became educators in math and science 
taking these same classes learned to teach these subjects in the same 
obscure way that places much of the burden of learning on the student.   
 
This is why many people think that you either have an aptitude for these 
subjects or don't. 3-4 generations of systematically indoctrinating 
educators to not teach these subjects but instead providing basic 
introduction and then forcing students to extrapolate beyond the 
information provided. The education system in these subjects are taught 
specifically so  only those who have natural aptitude or unbounded drive 
can succeed.  ﻿

to *BECOME* S.T.E.M. engineers. Would would *that* make sense? S.T.E.M. 
(Science Technology Electronics Medicine) jobs usually involve lots of 
typing, computer programming, circuitry, etc. Now, let me ask you this, 
when was the last time anybody has actually programmed a computer/robot in 
any grade? (if your school teaches robotics, you're in the minority, so 
don't worry. Oh, and also you're fortunate) When was the last time anybody 
has taken a computer class in school based solely on typing? When was the 
last time anybody has actually for a grade work with a mother board in 
school? Anybody? 
Now, I take robotics, so if you take any class like that, that's fine and 
dandy. But for those of you who don't even understand why there's 2 shift 
keys on a real keyboard (if you ever seen one these days), just keep in 
mind how many people have similar problems, then try to examine without 
overlooking anything, what is actually being taught to your children. 
S.P.R.K. Programs are the solution, but how often do we take that solution, 
and actually try to work something into schools that will teach them 
something useful that they will need for the real world? ﻿

comments.text:
So it turns out I love math.  And science.  And technology.  I found that 
out maybe halfway through my college career, after I'd escaped the last 
maths/science prerequisite for my degree and was no longer suffering the 
torture that is mathematics education.  I started loving math when I 
started studying anthropology, and passively began learning statistics just 
because they were an awesome way of putting the data I had found into 
perspective.  I started loving biology when I started trying to apply 
evolutionary theory in my study of human behaviour and it turned out that 
in order to do that you need to know, like, everything about everything.  I 
started loving computer science when I wanted prettier armour in Skyrim and 
one thing kind of lead to another.  THOSE are ways that you get addicted to 
math and science, and learn to love "solving difficult problems."
Being locked in a room with seventy other students and forced to listen to 
an instructor drawl about methods with no perceivable application, then 
required to go home and spend several hours drilling yourself on these 
abstracted representations of nonexistent scenarios (lest you be punished 
with failing grades and a lecture about how terrible your work ethic must 
be) is not how you get addicted.  In fact it's a good way to end up tired 
and resentful and wanting to get as far away from the subject as you 
possibly can.  By the time I was sixteen, I'd begun keeping my psychology 
and anatomy studies a secret because I'd learned that the second teachers 
and parents get their hands on my favourite subjects, they suck all the fun 
out of it.  I STILL have a hard time sharing what I'm up to with people I 
don't trust.

I'd also point out that maths and sciences have a serious lack of visible 
role models.  Growing up, Bill Nye was literally the only scientific 
celebrity I could name--and I it wasn't until I was well out of high school 
and stumbling around on facebook and youtube that I found out he was 
actually a real scientist, and not just a character portrayed by an actor. 
 I think that it's because there simply aren't enough maths and science 
people who utilize media to share their stories and their passions and show 
people what it looks like to care about science.  It's hard to follow in a 
great scientist or mathematician's footsteps if you don't even know who 
they are.﻿
